Appeal by special leave from the Award dated March 10, 1959, of the Industrial Tribunal
This is an appeal by special leave in an industrial matter
The appellant thereupon applied for special leave which was granted

On July 8, 1958, the appellant terminated the services of Sankaran under r. 18  a  of the Standing Orders without holding any departmental inquiry and the order was companymunicated to Sankaran the same day.

issues.text: Whether the employer is entitled under r.18A of the Standing Orders to an unfettered right to terminate the services of any permanent workman by giving 14 days' notice or paying 12 days' wages in lieu thereof, without scrutiny by the industrial tribunal for bona fides.

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of the appellant is that it is entitled under r. 18  a  of the Standing Orders to dispense with the service of any employee after complying with its terms. Rule 18  a  is in these terms- When the management desires to determine the services of any permanent workmen receiving 12 as. or more as daily wages, otherwise than under rule 21, he shall be given 14 days numberice or be paid 12 days wages.

issues.text: Whether the termination of Sankaran's services under r.18A without holding the departmental inquiry was a colourable exercise of power and not bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore if as in this case the employer wanted to take action for misconduct and then suddenly dropped the departmental proceedings which were intended to be held and decided to discharge the employee under r. 18  a  of the Standing orders, it was clearly a colourable exercise of the power under that rule in as much as that rule was used to get rid of an employee instead of following the course of holding an inquiry for misconduct

issues.text: Whether an industrial tribunal has jurisdiction to intervene and set aside termination of service under r.18A if it is a colourable exercise of power, result of victimisation or unfair labour practice, or capricious/arbitrary judged by reasonable man standard.

anchor.surface_text: It was of opinion that even in a case of this kind the requirement of bona fides is essential and if the terminataton of service is a colourable exercise of the power or as a result of victimisation or unfair labour praction the industrial tribunal would have the jurisdiction to intervene and set aside such termination. Further it held that where the termination of service is capricious, arbitrary or unnecessarily harsh on the part of the employer judged by normal standards of a reasonable man that may be considered evidence of victimisation

issues.text: Whether the employer must justify the termination under r.18A before the tribunal by proving misconduct or bona fides, even if no inquiry was held.

anchor.surface_text: In any case even if the inquiry was not held by the appellant and action was taken under r. 18  a  it is now well-settled, in view of the decisions cited above, that the employer could defend the action under r. 18 a  by leading evidence before the tribunal to show that there was in fact misconduct and therefore the action taken under r. 18 a  was bona fide and was not colourable exercise of the power under that rule.

issues.text: Whether the principle that motive is irrelevant in termination of service under contract or rules (as in government servants' cases under Arts. 309-311) applies to termination under standing orders of industrial employees.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant however relies on the decision of this Court in Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India. That was however a case of a public servant and the considerations that apply to such a case are in our opinion entirely different... It is true that the misconduct... may be the motive... nevertheless, if a right exists under the contract or the rule, to terminate the service, the motive operating on the mind of the Government is... wholly irrelevant.

issues.text: Whether the considerations under s.33 of the Industrial Disputes Act apply to proceedings under s.10 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant also drew our attention to another decision of this Court in The Patna Electric Supply Co. Ltd. Patna v. Bali Rai. That case in our opinion has no application to the facts of this case because that case dealt with an application under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act while the present proceedings are under s. 10 of the Act and the considerations which apply under s. 33 are different

arguments.claim: Employer is entitled under r.18A of Standing Orders to terminate services of permanent workman by giving 14 days notice or 12 days wages without any further scrutiny by industrial tribunal

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of the appellant is that it is entitled under r. 18  a  of the Standing Orders to dispense with the service of any employee after complying with its terms. Rule 18  a  is in these terms- When the management desires to determine the services of any permanent workmen receiving 12 as. or more as daily wages, otherwise than under rule 21, he shall be given 14 days numberice or be paid 12 days wages.

arguments.court_reasoning: Reason cannot be accepted at face value to dispense with inquiry intended for charged misconduct

arguments.court_reasoning: Position not accepted in industrial adjudication; tribunal can scrutinize even terminations under r.18A for bona fides

arguments.claim: Motive is irrelevant in termination of service if right exists under contract or rule, as in Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant however relies on the decision of this Court in Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India. That was however a case of a public servant and the considerations that apply to such a case are in our opinion entirely different. Stress was laid by the learned counsel on the observations at p. 862 where it was observed as follows- It is true that the misconduct, negligence inefficiency or other disqualification may be the motive or inducing factor which influences the Government to take action under the terms of the contract of employment or the specific service rule, nevertheless, if a right exists under the contract or the rule, to terminate the service, the motive operating on the mind of the Government is, as Chagla C. J. has said in Srinivas Ganesh v. Union of India supra , wholly irrelevant.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: oposed inquiry, if companyducted, would lead to further friction and deterioration in the rank and file of the employees in general and also that main

arguments.court_reasoning: Applies to government servants under Arts 310, 311, 309; different from industrial employees governed by industrial law

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant also drew our attention to another decision of this Court in The Patna Electric Supply Co. Ltd. Patna v. Bali Rai. That case in our opinion has no application to the facts of this case because that case dealt with an application under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act while the present proceedings are under s. 10 of the Act and the considerations which apply under s. 33 are different

arguments.court_reasoning: That case under s.33; present under s.10 with different considerations

arguments.claim: Bona fides required even in termination by notice under standing orders; tribunal can intervene if colourable, victimisation or unfair labour practice

anchor.surface_text: As far back as 1952, the Labour Appellate Tribunal had occasion to consider this matter relating to discharge by notice or in lieu thereof by payment of wages for a certain period without assigning any reason  see Buckingham and Carnatic Co. Ltd. Etg. v. Workers of the Company. etc.   1 . It was of opinion that even in a case of this kind the requirement of bona fides is essential and if the termination of service is a colourable exercise of the power or as a result of victimisation or unfair labour practice the industrial tribunal would have the jurisdiction to intervene

arguments.claim: Termination capricious, arbitrary or harsh judged by reasonable man standard is evidence of victimisation or unfair labour practice

anchor.surface_text: Further it held that where the termination of service is capricious, arbitrary or unnecessarily harsh on the part of the employer judged by normal standards of a reasonable man that may be considered evidence of victimisation or unfair labour practice.

arguments.claim: Even if no departmental inquiry held, employer can defend r.18A termination before tribunal by proving misconduct to show bona fides

anchor.surface_text: In any case even if the inquiry was not held by the appellant and action was taken under r. 18  a  it is now well-settled, in view of the decisions cited above, that the employer could defend the action under r. 18 a  by leading evidence before the tribunal to show that there was in fact misconduct and therefore the action taken under r. 18 a  was bona fide and was not colourable exercise of the power under that rule.

arguments.claim: No evidence to prove what actually happened on June 21, 1958 afternoon though something seemed to have happened

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal held that something seemed to have happened on the afternoon of June 21, 1958 but there was no evidence to prove what had actually happened.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: termination of service is capricious, arbitrary or unnecessarily harsh on the part of the employer judged by numbermal standards of a reasonable man

arguments.court_reasoning: Employer did not lead sufficient evidence before tribunal

arguments.claim: Sankaran denied the allegations of misconduct though admitted coming to mill for wages

anchor.surface_text: Sankaran gave an explanation the same day denying the allegations of fact made against him, though he admitted that he had come to the mill at the relevant time for taking his wages for that week.

arguments.claim: Industrial tribunal has jurisdiction under s.10 to scrutinize terminations under standing orders unlike under s.33

anchor.surface_text: That case in our opinion has no application to the facts of this case because that case dealt with an application under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act while the present proceedings are under s. 10 of the Act and the considerations which apply under s. 33 are different in many respects from those which apply to an adjudication under s. 10.

holdings.text: The appellant's claim to an unfettered right under r.18A of the Standing Orders to terminate services of any permanent workman by 14 days notice or 12 days wages without scrutiny by industrial tribunal cannot be accepted as it negatives security of service secured through industrial adjudication.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this claim of the appellant cannot be accepted, and it is too late in the day for an employer to raise such a claim for it amounts to a claim to hire and fire an employee as the employer pleases and thus completely negatives security of service which has been secured to industrial employees through industrial adjudication for over a long period of time number.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects hire-and-fire claim as contrary to long-standing industrial adjudication protecting security of service; cites prior tribunal decisions.

holdings.text: Even in termination by notice under standing orders like r.18A, bona fides is essential; industrial tribunal has jurisdiction to intervene if colourable exercise of power, victimisation, unfair labour practice, or capricious/arbitrary/harsh by reasonable man standard.

anchor.surface_text: As far back as 1952, the Labour Appellate Tribunal had occasion to consider this matter relating to discharge by notice or in lieu thereof by payment of wages for a certain period without assigning any reason see Buckingham and Carnatic Co. Ltd. Etg. v. Workers of the Company. etc. 1 . It was of opinion that even in a case of this kind the requirement of bona fides is essential and if the termination of service is a colourable exercise of the power or as a result of victimisation or unfair labour praction the industrial tribunal would have the jurisdiction to intervene and set aside such termination. Further it held that where the termination of service is capricious, arbitrary or unnecessarily harsh on the part of the employer judged by normal standards of a reasonable man that may be considered evidence of victimisation or unfair labour practice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Approves 1952 Labour Appellate Tribunal view upheld by Supreme Court in Chartered Bank and Assam Oil cases; applies to r.18A terminations.

holdings.text: Termination under r.18A after intending and initiating disciplinary inquiry for misconduct but dropping it is a colourable exercise of power.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore if as in this case the employer wanted to take action for misconduct and then suddenly dropped the departmental proceedings which were intended to be held and decided to discharge the employee under r. 18 a of the Standing orders, it was clearly a colourable exercise of the power under that rule in as much as that rule was used to get rid of an employee instead of following the course of holding an inquiry for misconduct, notice for which had been given to the employee and for which a departmental inquiry was intended to be held.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies bona fides requirement to facts: charge-sheet served, suspension, but inquiry dropped for r.18A.

holdings.text: The reason given in termination order that proposed inquiry would cause friction and prejudice discipline cannot be accepted to dispense with inquiry for charged misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: The reason given by the appellant in the order terminating the services of Sankaran of July 8, 1958, namely, that the proposed inquiry, if conducted, would lead to further friction and deterioration in the rank and file of the employees in general and also that maintenance of discipline in the undertaking would be prejudiced if Sankaran were retained in service, cannot be accepted at its face value so that the necessity for an inquiry intended to be held for misconduct actually charged might be done away with.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cannot accept employer's stated reason at face value when avoiding charged misconduct inquiry.

holdings.text: Even without holding departmental inquiry, employer can defend r.18A termination before tribunal by proving misconduct to show action was bona fide, not colourable.

anchor.surface_text: In any case even if the inquiry was not held by the appellant and action was taken under r. 18 a it is now well-settled, in view of the decisions cited above, that the employer could defend the action under r. 18 a by leading evidence before the tribunal to show that there was in fact misconduct and therefore the action taken under r. 18 a was bona fide and was not colourable exercise of the power under that rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled from cited decisions; tribunal pointed out appellant produced only two witnesses, withheld key ones without explanation.

holdings.text: Position that employer need justify nothing after acting under r.18A not accepted in industrial adjudication.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant however urges that the employer was empowered to take action under r. 18 a of the Standing orders and having taken action under that rule, there was nothing for it to justify before the tribunal. We have already said that this position cannot be accepted in industrial adjudication relating to termination of service of an employee

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contrary to long course of industrial adjudication upheld by Supreme Court.

holdings.text: Principle that motive irrelevant in contractual termination (Parshotam Lal Dhingra) applies to government servants under Arts. 309-311, not to industrial employees under standing orders.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant however relies on the decision of this Court in Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India. That was however a case of a public servant and the considerations that apply to such a case are in our opinion entirely different... Articles 310 and 311 of the Constitution apply to government servants and it is in the light of those Articles read with the Rules framed under Art. 309 that questions relating to termination of service of government servants have to be considered. No such constitutional provisions have to be considered when one is dealing with industrial employees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes govt servants (constitutional protections) from industrial employees (industrial law scrutiny).

holdings.text: Industrial tribunal under s.10 can scrutinize r.18A termination for bona fides; considerations under s.33 different.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant also drew our attention to another decision of this Court in The Patna Electric Supply Co. Ltd. Patna v. Bali Rai. That case in our opinion has no application to the facts of this case because that case dealt with an application under s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act while the present proceedings are under s. 10 of the Act and the considerations which apply under s. 33 are different in many respects from those which apply to an adjudication under s. 10.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Patna Electric case as under s.33, not applicable to s.10 adjudication.

holdings.text: Tribunal correctly held termination colourable and not bona fide; appellant failed to prove misconduct before tribunal by withholding key witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The industrial court in our opinion has the right to inquire into the causes that might have led to termination of service even under a rule like 18 a and if it is satisfied that the action taken under such a rule was a colourable exercise of power and was not bona fide or was a result of victimisation or unfair labour practice it would have jurisdiction to intervene and set aside such termination. In this case the tribunal held that the exercise of power was colourable and it cannot be said that view is incorrect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant rested on unfettered right claim, failed to justify with evidence; upholds tribunal.

precedents.case_name: Buckingham and Carnatic Co. Ltd. v. Workers of the Company
precedents.cited_proposition: requirement of bona fides essential for termination by notice or payment in lieu without reason; termination invalid if colourable, victimization, unfair labour practice, capricious, arbitrary or harsh

precedents.citation: The Chartered Bank, Bombay v. The Chartered Bank Employees Union 1

anchor.surface_text: The Chartered Bank, Bombay v. The Chartered Bank Employees Union 1 . and Assam Oil Company v. Its Workmen 2 . Therefore if as in this case the employer wanted to take action for misconduct and then suddenly dropped the departmental proceedings which were intended to be held and decided to discharge the employee under r. 18  a  of the Standing orders, it was clearly a companyourable exercise of the power under that rule in as much as that rule was used to get rid of an employee instead of following the course of holding an inquiry for misconduct, numberice for which had been given to the employee and for which a departmental inquiry was intended to be held.

precedents.case_name: Chartered Bank, Bombay v. Chartered Bank Employees Union
precedents.cited_proposition: approval of requirement of bona fides for termination by notice without reason

precedents.citation: Assam Oil Company v. Its Workmen 2

anchor.surface_text: Assam Oil Company v. Its Workmen 2 . Therefore if as in this case the employer wanted to take action for misconduct and then suddenly dropped the departmental proceedings which were intended to be held and decided to discharge the employee under r. 18  a  of the Standing orders, it was clearly a companyourable exercise of the power under that rule in as much as that rule was used to get rid of an employee instead of following the course of holding an inquiry for misconduct, numberice for which had been given to the employee and for which a departmental inquiry was intended to be held. The reason given by the appellant in the order terminating the services of Sankaran of July 8, 1958, namely, that the proposed inquiry, if companyducted, would lead to further friction and deterioration in the rank and file of the employees in general and also that maintenance of discipline in the undertaking would be prejudiced if Sankaran were retained in service, cannot be accepted at its face value so that the necessity for an inquiry intended to be held for misconduct actually charged might be done away with.

precedents.case_name: Assam Oil Company v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: approval of requirement of bona fides for termination by notice without reason

precedents.citation: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India. 1

anchor.surface_text: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India. 1  That was however a case of a public servant and the companysiderations that apply to such a case are in our opinion entirely different. Stress was laid by the learned companynsel on the observations at p. 862 where it was observed as follows- It is true that the misconduct, negligence inefficiency or other disqualification may be the motive or inducing factor which influences the Government to take action under the terms of the companytract of employment or the specific service rule, nevertheless, if a right exists under the companytract or the rule, to terminate the service, the motive operating on the mind of the Government is, as Chagla C. J. has said in Srinivas Ganesh v. Union of India 2   supra , wholly irrelevant.

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: motive irrelevant if contractual right to terminate service exists
precedents.cited_holding: if a right exists under the contract or the rule, to terminate the service, the motive operating on the mind of the Government is wholly irrelevant

precedents.citation: Srinivas Ganesh v. Union of India 2 supra

anchor.surface_text: Srinivas Ganesh v. Union of India 2   supra , wholly irrelevant. It is urged that the same principle should be applied to industrial adjudication. It is enough to say that the position of government servants stands on an entirely different footing as compared to industrial employees. Articles 310 and 311 of the Constitution apply to government servants and it is in the light of those Articles read with the Rules framed under Art. 309 that questions relating to termination of service of government servants have to be considered. No such constitutional provisions have to be considered when one is dealing with industrial employees.

precedents.case_name: Srinivas Ganesh v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: motive wholly irrelevant for termination under contract right

precedents.citation: The Patna Electric Supply Co. Ltd. Patna v. Bali Rai 1

anchor.surface_text: The Patna Electric Supply Co. Ltd. Patna v. Bali Rai 1 . precedents.case_name: Patna Electric Supply Co. Ltd., Patna v. Bali Rai
precedents.cited_proposition: considerations under s. 33 of Industrial Disputes Act

edges.explanation: The holding affirms the industrial tribunal's jurisdiction to intervene in terminations under r.18A that involve colourable exercise of power, victimisation, or unfair labour practice, directly addressing the issue raised.

anchor.surface_text: As far back as 1952, the Labour Appellate Tribunal had occasion to consider this matter relating to discharge by notice or in lieu thereof by payment of wages for a certain period without assigning any reason see Buckingham and Carnatic Co. Ltd. Etg. v. Workers of the Company. etc. 1 . It was of opinion that even in a case of this kind the requirement of bona fides is essential and if the termination of service is a colourable exercise of the power or as a result of victimisation or unfair labour praction the industrial tribunal would have the jurisdiction to intervene and set aside such termination. Further it held that where the termination of service is capricious, arbitrary or unnecessarily harsh on the part of the employer judged by normal standards of a reasonable man that may be considered evidence of victimisation or unfair labour practice.

In this case the tribunal held that the exercise of power was colourable and it cannot be said that view is incorrect. The appellant failed to satisfy the tribunal when the matter came before it for adjudication that the exercise of the power in this case was bona fide and was number companyourable. It companyld have easily done so by producing satisfactory evidence but it seems to have rested upon its right that numbersuch justification was required and therefore having failed to justify its action must suffer the companysequences.

Therefore if as in this case the employer wanted to take action for misconduct and then suddenly dropped the departmental proceedings which were intended to be held and decided to discharge the employee under r. 18 a of the Standing orders, it was clearly a colourable exercise of the power under that rule in as much as that rule was used to get rid of an employee instead of following the course of holding an inquiry for misconduct, notice for which had been given to the employee and for which a departmental inquiry was intended to be held.

In this case the tribunal held that the exercise of power was colourable and it cannot be said that view is incorrect. The appellant failed to satisfy the tribunal when the matter came before it for adjudication that the exercise of the power in this case was bona fide and was number companyourable. It companyld have easily done so by producing satisfactory evidence but it seems to have rested upon its right that numbersuch justification was required and therefore having failed to justify its action must suffer the companysequences.

In this case the tribunal held that the exercise of power was colourable and it cannot be said that view is incorrect. The appellant failed to satisfy the tribunal when the matter came before it for adjudication that the exercise of the power in this case was bona fide and was number companyourable. It companyld have easily done so by producing satisfactory evidence but it seems to have rested upon its right that numbersuch justification was required and therefore having failed to justify its action must suffer the companysequences.

In any case even if the inquiry was not held by the appellant and action was taken under r. 18 a it is now well-settled, in view of the decisions cited above, that the employer could defend the action under r. 18 a by leading evidence before the tribunal to show that there was in fact misconduct and therefore the action taken under r. 18 a was bona fide and was not colourable exercise of the power under that rule.
